text: [music playing]

AYESHA TEJPAR: Pop up shops
aren't exactly a new concept

in the world of
retail, but they're

thriving in the current market
as traditional retailers look

for different ways
to engage shoppers
and bring them into stores.

SUSAN REDA: The challenge for
pop-ups are to keep them fresh,

and I think we're
seeing some hybrids

as retailers look for what I
can do to make it different.

AYESHA TEJPAR: West
Elm, primarily known

for modern furniture
and home decor,

has set itself apart
with a local twist.

MO MULLEN: Everything
we do at West Elm
is designed to make an impact.

So we started West Elm
LOCAL in that spirit,

and the goal was to celebrate
communities across America.

That work has grown since then
to support over 800 makers
and designers around the world.

AYESHA TEJPAR: West
Elm now features

locally sourced collections
in all of its stores.

But the company
has taken it a step

further with a pop-up shop in
Washington DC's Union Market.

Here local makers create and
sell their designs in-house
while engaging with customers.

MO MULLEN: We live in an
incredibly digital world,

but there's still a
yearning and a desire
for that human connection.

And I think this is an
experience that offers people

a chance to get to
know their neighbors,

and not just get to
know them, actually--

one step further,
support their neighbors
in a really tangible way.

AYESHA TEJPAR: Samantha Testa
spent six weeks creating
her artwork in this space.

SAMANTHA TESTA: My business
is predominantly paper goods.
I do a lot of custom art.
I'm a fine artist by nature.

I was creating here,
I was meeting people,

people were able to see
what I was creating,

and it made the art a
little bit more accessible.

This has really given
me the opportunity
to start thinking large.

AYESHA TEJPAR: And this location
even features more pop-ups
within the actual pop-up shop.

JONATHAN WOSSENE:
The first thing

that people say when they come
in is, what is that smell?

And we always point down we
say, hey this is our candles.

AYESHA TEJPAR: Melted Element
is an all natural candle company
that started online last year.

JONATHAN WOSSENE:
It's very key for us

to get out here and have people
smell them, interact with us,

tell us what we
could improve on.

SUSAN REDA: If you can set up a
pop-up shop, tell your story--

this is something that's
so important today.
We want to be storytellers.

We want to tell the
story of our brand,
tell the story of our mission.

This is an opportunity
to do that,

to do it in a couple
of weeks, to create
excitement and then move on.

AYESHA TEJPAR: Businesses
both small and large

benefit from creating that kind
of experience for consumers.

MO MULLEN: And I think
the question becomes how

do you do that in a
meaningful way that

feels like an extension
of your brand?

AYESHA TEJPAR: West Elm
isn't alone in that thinking.

SUSAN REDA: Banana Republic
recently partnered with Olivia

Palermo, and she is online
creating little capsules
of items that she really likes.

She's going to have some
pop-up shops in key cities.
It's something new.

It's energy for a retailer who's
been around for a long time.
[music playing]

The future of retail
lies in three things:

content, community,
and commerce.

And the blend of those is where
we're seeing retailers succeed.

Pop-ups are definitely
here to stay.

AYESHA TEJPAR: For CNN,
I am Ayesha Tejpar.
